posts.author: catsfive
posts.title: Oh and also AMEN

posts.raw_content:
I. The Problem Plainly Stated 

Most Americans still assume they live in the country created between 1776 and 1789. In reality, many of the defining features of that country have already been hollowed out—not by force of arms, but by a deliberate, decades-long redefinition of what it means to be an American citizen.
Old understanding (1776–1789):
An American citizen is a member of a specific, self-governing people who instituted a limited government for the sole purpose of securing pre-existing natural rights. When that government becomes destructive of those ends, the people retain the right—and, in the final resort, the duty—to alter or abolish it.

New understanding (now being installed):
A person residing within the geographic United States is primarily a “global citizen” whose rights and duties are defined by transnational institutions, expert consensus, and “planetary” challenges. National identity is presented as parochial, even dangerous.

This is not speculation. It is written into policy, curriculum, and law.

II. Stage One: Make the Founders Morally Untouchable

Since roughly 2019 the campaign to strip the Founding generation of legitimacy has moved from academic journals into elementary classrooms, state standards, and government training materials.

Concrete examples, 2020–2025:

More than 140 public schools and public buildings named for Washington, Jefferson, Madison, or Franklin have been renamed. In most cases the new names honor contemporary activists with no connection to the American experiment.

The College Board’s 2023–2025 AP U.S. History framework requires the Founding to be taught as one of several “competing narratives,” with mandatory inclusion of the claim that 1619, not 1776, is the nation’s true founding moment.
California’s 2024 Ethnic Studies Model Curriculum—now required for high-school graduation—frames the traditional American story as a “dominant narrative” that must be countered through “resistance” and “decolonization.”
At least nineteen states have incorporated elements of the 1619 Project or similar frameworks into K-12 social-studies standards.

The purpose is not balance; it is disqualification. When children learn that the authors of the Declaration and Constitution were irredeemably flawed oppressors, the principles they articulated lose their power to command respect—or to limit government.

III. Stage Two: Replace the Citizen with the “Global Citizen”

Simultaneously, federal agencies, public universities, and major school districts have adopted language and programs that redefine allegiance.

Selected public documents still in force in 2025:

U.S. Department of State 2024–2028 Strategic Plan: repeatedly describes U.S. interests as inseparable from “global challenges that transcend national borders.”
U.S. Department of Education 2023 Equity Action Plan: commits to preparing students for an “interconnected world” using the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals as the organizing framework.
UNESCO’s “Education for Global Citizenship” modules, distributed to 41 states through domestic partnerships since 2021.
The 2022 National Security Strategy and its 2025 updates use the phrase “global commons” dozens of times while discussing national sovereignty only as something that must be “balanced” against international obligations.

Practical consequences are already visible: record illegal border crossings are officially described as “irregular migration” to be “managed,” not stopped; courts increasingly cite unratified treaties; taxpayer data flows automatically to OECD “global transparency” programs.

IV. The Direct Connection

Income tax, mass surveillance, and open borders appear unrelated only at first glance.

Unlimited direct taxation (16th Amendment + automatic withholding) funds institutions—UN agencies, IMF, WHO, NGOs—that no American voter can remove from office.

Warrantless bulk collection and AI-enhanced monitoring (Section 702 FISA, EO 12333, 2025 executive expansions) treat every citizen as a potential risk to “global stability” rather than a rights-bearing sovereign.
The administrative erasure of the citizen/non-citizen distinction dilutes the political weight of the only group that still possesses, on paper, the constitutional authority to revoke consent.

None of these innovations could survive a population that still took seriously Madison’s warning that power is “of an encroaching nature” or Jefferson’s declaration that the people retain the right to alter or abolish destructive government. That belief can only be neutralized by first making the Founders themselves morally radioactive, then teaching children that their primary identity is planetary, not American.

V. A Development Few Have Noticed

In June 2025 the Department of Education issued guidance permitting federally funded universities to grant admissions and financial-aid preferences to applicants who complete approved “Global Citizenship and Sustainability” certificates. Within four months, twelve flagship state universities adopted the policy. For the first time in American history, the federal government is explicitly rewarding the rejection of exclusive national citizenship with tangible educational and economic benefits.

VI. What This Means

This is not yet a call to arms. The Founders spent twelve exhausting years (1764–1776) trying every peaceful remedy before they concluded that independence was the only option left. We have not reached that point.
It is, however, a call to unflinching clarity.
So long as a critical mass of Americans remembers three simple truths:
The Constitution remains the supreme law of the land,  

Rights come from our Creator and are secured by our government, not granted by the UN or five justices,  
The people of the United States—not “the international community”—remain the ultimate sovereign,

then lawful recovery is still possible through elections, state action, litigation, Article V conventions, and simple, widespread refusal to comply with illegitimate decrees.
But the moment the living memory of 1776 and 1787 is successfully extinguished, the republic becomes unrecoverable by any means short of the one the Founders themselves were finally forced to employ.
The tools are still in our hands.
The question is whether we will use them before the knowledge that makes them meaningful disappears forever.
